text:
PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

(Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask. where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: George C. Craig
Address: Athabasca
Birthplace: Birth, Ayrshire, Scotland

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1932
Where did you set up housekeeping?
Where had you been living before that? At home with my parents
For how many people did you prepare meals?
How far was it to your nearest store?
How often could a visit be made to the store?
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Flour made in Saskatoon by mill owned by Archie McNaughton. It was called Champion
In what quantities did you buy it? Usually 500 or 600 lbs.
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.15
How much did you use graham flour? Rarely if ever
Whole wheat flour?
Was flour milled locally? Yes How far away? 20 miles What year? About 1925
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? Don't know now
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? Yes Whole Wheat? Farina?
Other?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No
How did you grind it?

My mother if she was living could supply much of the information you ask for, but as I was only 18 years of age at that time, I had no interest whatever in food except to eat it so price of anything in the food line never bothered me, as that was the problem of my father's mother.
PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail us to:

Where did you set up housekeeping? _______________________________________

For how many people did you prepare meals? ________________________________

How far was it to your nearest store? ______________________________________

How often could a visit be made to the store? ________________________________

What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? ____________________

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? ____________________

In what quantities did you buy it? Usually _______ lbs or _______ kgs. ________

What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? _______

How much did you use graham flour? ______________________________________

Whole wheat flour? _____________________________________________________

Was flour milled locally? ___________________________________________________

What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? ______________________

What other grain products did you use? ______________________________________

Cornmeal? ______________________________________________________________

Other? _________________________________________________________________

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? __________________________________

How did you grind it? _____________________________________________________

My mother if she was doing cloud supply needed my help. I heard no artificial substitutes in food age at Rev. End, I heard no artificial substitutes in food except to eat it in place of anything in the food line unless bothered me, so that was the problem of my father's mother.
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? Usually 200 lbs.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? 60¢

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Butternut Rogers

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 10 lbs.

At what price? $5.50

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? By owning cows.

Butter? Made at home. Eggs? Owned chickens.

What was the price of butter? 25¢ per lb. How many eggs? 75¢ per dozen.

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes. How? Water glass.

Did you make butter? Yes. Cheese?

What kind of cheese?

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Antelope, deer, ducks, geese. Winter meat was always a store (frozen).

How did you get fresh meat? Bought some, traded for some, given by neighbors.

How often did you get fresh meat? Usually in the fall weather.

How did you preserve meat? Only with a house made very strong.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Yes.

If so what year was it organized? About 1918.

Did you use game? Yes. What kinds? Antelope, ducks, geese.

For how long? Still going but not as much.

What part did fish play in the family diet? None.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Any we got were canned.

Kinds? Canned salmon only.
2.

3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 60 lbs.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? $1.50

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Blue Heart

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? No. 8

At what price?

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days?

Butter? Yes

What was the price of butter? 25¢

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes

Did you make butter? Yes

What kind of cheese?

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Antelope, venison, bear, fish

How did you get fresh meat? About every two weeks

How often did you get fresh meat? About every two weeks

How did you preserve meat? Only with a brief period, very shortly

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Yes

If so what year was it organized? About 1918

Did you use game? Yes

For how long? Still hunting but not so much

What part did fish play in the family diet? None

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? None

Kinds? Ham, salami, pork
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? Black At what price? 9¢

What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Coffee Beans

Price? What other beverages were used? None

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping? 4¢

Could you get potatoes at the store? Yes

If not, where from? Usually grown at home

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:

Potatoes 1909 Cabbage 1909 Carrots 1909 Onions 1909

Turnips 1909 Beets 1909

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? 2 lbs

How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? By the box

What weight? 20 lbs How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? Box

What was the price of prunes? I forget

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? No

peas? corn? beans? Saskatoons?

other foods?

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? Not before 1915

What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? Didn't do it yet

What year did you first preserve meat by canning? Not yet

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Some

To what extent? Very little

Did you make your own vinegar? No
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? Black tea. At what price? I think about 40¢.

What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Coffee beans.

Price? 

What other beverages were used?

Other foods?

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? Royal yeast Cake

Did you make yeast for your own use? No Using starter?

Using hops? Salt rising?

Did you buy baking powder? Yes Baking soda? Yes

Cream of tartar? Yes Did you make your own baking powder? No

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout)

How far was this water from your home?

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank)

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

We dug two wells, both 6 feet deep, but the water was hard / alkaline / actually unfit for human use, 1 for years / up to the present we have hauled first class water by analysis 5-7 miles for domestic use.

Hand to Remember

These items

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout)

How far was this water from your home? We hauled water 9 miles.

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

We dug two wells, both of them deep, but the water was hard, alkaline. Initially unfit for human use. For years we kept it in present use by boiling first class water, by analysis 5% milk for domestic use.
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? [Handwritten]

If you made your own, did you use lye? [Handwritten]

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? [Handwritten]

Sunlight, "Pears," "Crest"

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? [Handwritten]

Where did you get your fuel? [Handwritten]

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

When the Railway came in 1907, we used coal/wood & brought in by the G.N.R., then oil came into use about 1948 and now in our town village of Netherhills, natural gas is the only fuel used.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) [Handwritten]

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) [Handwritten]

By whom was your first cook stove made? [Handwritten]

What year was it purchased? 1907 Price? [Handwritten]

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) [Handwritten]

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) [Handwritten]

When did you first see enamel ware? [Handwritten]

Aluminum? About 20 years ago (1932)

   *Notes:*
   - The Kishmery came in 1909, but stood until 1920.

   *Additional note:* In the early fuel used:

   *Notes:*

   - How long did it last? *(Give date)*
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Practically all food was wrapped by the storekeeper & he used old newspapers when his brown paper played out. Usually tied up with string and cloth or other tape were unknown in 1906.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

1906 Breakfast Porridge, slice of salted pork, coffee Bread, butter / jam. Syrup

Dinner Potatoes (if we had them) canned meat (if no fresh meat) dried apples (in pie) bread / butter / jam Possibly prunes Supper, fried potatoes (if any) baked beans, bread butter / jam Syrup dripping butter, dripping was always kept / used instead of butter

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? ..........

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

I cannot recall the first Reel Family gathering for Xmas.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

I remember one time when my brother left for Saskatchewan I left me in charge of the stock. There was little food left; he remained longer than expected, I was forced to subsist on Boiled Wheat / syrup for 5 or 6 days while I didn't starve, I've never had the least notion of trying that diet again.
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS
Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received
with the food you purchased (extra those where possible).

For January all food was wrapped by the store keeper
I do not recall any newspapers or other items being paper
packed out. Usually they were packed with cheese and eggs.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest
year you can remember. Give the year, and list the numbers of the family
within the age at the time. State the approximate amount, e.g., "half a
bottle."

1906 Breakfast Porridge, apple sauce, porridge tea
Bread, butter, jam, or applesauce
Dinner Potatoes (if we had them), canned meat (if fresh meat),
chopped apples (in pie), bread, butter, jam
Supper, fried potatoes (yams), brown bread, brown butter, jam,
knocking butter, drinking chocolate, kipper, usual amount of milk.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada?
Give the year and list those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

I cannot recall the first Reit family
gathering for Xmas.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally
produced foods? Give details.

I remember this time after my brother left for Saskatchewan.
I left me in charge of the stock! There was little food
left, he remained longer than expected. I was forced
to subsist on boiled wheat / syrup for several days
while I didn't obtain, I've never had the chance before.

A very hard diet again.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Maybe there's little difference except that now the housewife has so many labor-saving appliances, automatic stoves that less work is actually used in cooking a much larger meal, than would have been incurred 50 years ago when all she had was a cook stove equipped for burning wood, maybe the wood was only green poplar poles.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

When the Railway arrived here in 1909, we gradually lost the habit of preparing for 6 months supply, I bought in smaller quantities I had more variety; I would say the change began in 1909 but was not in full swing until after the first war, maybe 1920.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandizing, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

Not much more to add, except a word about tobacco. We used to purchase tobacco in large packages with a pipe imbedded in the mixture. This was French Canadian "Tobac" it wasn't nice to smoke, after being used to better prepared stuff, but when we ran out of smoking altogether we used to dry the tea leaves, mix them with the inner bark of the Red Willow (Smoke that). It smelled awful & tasted worse! Its usual name was "Kini Kini". Many matches were of the Sulphur variety & when ignited, you had to wait until the Sulphur burned away before lighting your pipe, as the Sulphur fumes were very powerful & not at all palatable.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Maybe there's little difference except that now the housewife has so many labour-saving appliances, automatic stoves that less work is actually used in cooking a much larger meal, than would have been incurred 50 years ago when all she had was a coal stove equipped for burning wood, (maybe the wood was only green poplar poles).

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

When the Railway arrived here in 1909, we gradually lost the habit of preparing for 6 months supply, I bought in smaller quantities I had more variety; I would say the change began in 1909 but was not in full swing until after the first war, maybe 1920.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

Not much more to add, except a word about tobacco. We used to purchase tobacco in large packages with a pipe imbedded in the mixture. This was French Canadian "Jobac" & it wasn't nice to smoke, after being used to better prepared stuff, but when we ran out of smoking cigarettes we used to dry the tea leaves & mix them with the inner bark of the Red Willow & smoke that. It smelled awful & tasted worse! Its usual name was "Kini Kini". Many matches were of the Sulphur variety & when ignited, you had to wait until the Sulphur burned away before lighting your pipe, as the Sulphur fumes were very powerful & not at all palatable.
Oxford
